values:
What a weird time to be alive.

I'm glad that I've never tried to be anything other than what I am, even if being that has cost me.

visited 37 states (74%)
Create your own visited map of The United States
visited 4 states (1.77%)
Create your own visited map of The World

There are no fairy tales. I use to believe in them until I realized that they were mainly composed of a very simplistic plot manufactured to showcase moral righteousness, wherein an unethical hag is rolled down a hill inside a spikey barrel, usually into a river for good measure. The happy ending with the protagonists is universally lacking in resolution and everyone seems to go away unimpeded by the massively fucked up thing that just happened, but it's obvious there is a healthy dose of minutae that goes without mention and is kept secretive but maybe just implied a tiny bit. It's sort of like Catholicism, I suppose.

I've been meaning to get my food blog up and running for some time now, as I claimed my blogspot account ages ago. I truly intended to spend more time polishing it up and making it spiffy looking but realistically, it's just some place online where I can go to blather about cooking and baking and where my friends can find my recipes.

That having been stated, I introduce to you the rough draft of:

http://amandoline.blogspot.com/

There will be some alterations made once I start actively posting, but there you go.

I quite enjoy this portion of the Brokencyde wikipedia entry, and that no one from the band or label has bothered to dispute/"correct" it:

"Metal Edge Magazine has called Brokencyde "fucking horrendous".[10] Thrash Magazine has called them "a mockery to the world of music".[11] Another metal magazine, Decibel, has repeatedly made fun of the band, mentioning them in a interview with the group Big Business, and once ironically referring to then as their "favorite screamo-crunk band". British commentator Warren Ellis calls Brokencyde's "Freaxxx" music video "a near-perfect snapshot of everything that’s shit about this point in the culture".[12] Says August Brown of the Los Angeles Times, "The 'Albucrazy'-based band has done for MySpace emo what some think Soulja Boy did for hip-hop: turn their career into a kind of macro-performance art that exists so far beyond the tropes of irony and sincerity that to ask 'are they kidding?' is like trying to peel an onion to get to a perceived central core that, in the end, does not exist and renders all attempts to reassemble the pieces futile."[13]

"If this is the future of rock music, we're fucking outta here", - wrote Kerrang! in it's January 2009 What the F* is up with Screamo Crunk feature. Placing the 'irritation factor' mark at level "very high", the magazine concluded - "Thanks to their tacky, lightweight and frankly rubbish sound, they've probably only got a shelf life of about six months". "

My Tramontina 6.5 qt. Dutch oven arrived for pick-up today, so I made the trip to the Unidentified Circle of Hell (Oakland Walmart) to retrieve it.  The UCH was especially torturous on the 4th of July, which I had readied myself to face but still truly was not prepared for.  Nonetheless, I picked up my order as well as $100 worth of random other stuff in hopes that I will not have to return to the UCH for quite some time.  I made a sort-of impuse purchase of the Neutrogena Total Skin Renewal thingy and refill pads because I've read promising things about it and my skin has been all over the map lately and I have a feeling a good exfoliation would help considerably.  Sometimes I have to give in to my inborn female desire for cosmetic products.

The Dutch oven looks great, though as the reviews I had read said it's heavier than more expensive models.  Still, it was rated very kindly by America's Test Kitchen/Cook's Illustrated and short of having to find a new metal handle (I can probably just use a cabinet knob), I don't see much difference between it and my parents' Le Creuset.  The Tramontina was $45+tax, which is far less than most Le Creusets sell for.  Plus, mine has the advantage of being seasoned with the sweat and tears of slave labourers!

Ben and I grilled a lovely beer-can chicken for 4th of July dinner on our 18.5" Weber charcoal grill.  "What?!??" you may ask yourself, "how have you done beer-can chicken on that particular grill?  It does not fit.  The lid would not come anywhere near closing well enough to do this successfully.  What manner of wizardry have you performed to allow such a feat?"

I obtained three equally sized broken bricks from the backyard.  Rocks would also work.  Then, Ben started the charcoal chimney, with the usual newspaper soaked in discarded rancid vegetable oil (reuse!) resting beneath to get the coals red.  When ready, we distributed the coals around the brick-rocks.  We added a scant few more coals on top of the red-hots and let them smolder, than placed a cast iron skillet on the brick-rocks.  Beer-can chicken on a beer-can chicken stand was placed in the skillet, and usual grilling was done. 

After it was clear the coals were burning away, we added soaked wood chips on top of the coals to produce smoked goodness.  Because the chicken was so much nearer to the heat than it would be on a grate, I had to wrap it with aluminum foil after about 30 minutes and also added water for steam to the cast iron skillet such that the bird did not dry out.  Next time I will do this step at the beginning and then remove the aluminum and brown the skin at the end of the cooking time to ensure the chicken remains moist.

For a first try, the results were glorious.  The chicken had been rubbed in the BBQ rub recipe from Steven Raichlen's terrific book "How to Grill," except I had added a bit of ancho pepper for a hint of smokiness and in lieu of hickory smoked salt I sprinkled some liquid smoke on sea salt and stirred that into the rub.  I had additionally placed 8 halved cloves of garlic under the skin of the chicken on the breast meat because garlic roasted inside of a chicken is a thing of beauty.

Also served:
-red cabbage, carrot and jicama slaw in a shallot-jalepeno vinaigrette
-steamed fresh green beans
-grilled corn on the cob

http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2008/jan/14/facebook

"Thiel's philosophical mentor is one René Girard of Stanford University, proponent of a theory of human behaviour called mimetic desire. Girard reckons that people are essentially sheep-like and will copy one another without much reflection. The theory would also seem to be proved correct in the case of Thiel's virtual worlds: the desired object is irrelevant; all you need to know is that human beings will tend to move in flocks. Hence financial bubbles. Hence the enormous popularity of Facebook. Girard is a regular at Thiel's intellectual soirees. What you don't hear about in Thiel's philosophy, by the way, are old-fashioned real-world concepts such as art, beauty, love, pleasure and truth.

The internet is immensely appealing to neocons such as Thiel because it promises a certain sort of freedom in human relations and in business, freedom from pesky national laws, national boundaries and suchlike. The internet opens up a world of free trade and laissez-faire expansion. Thiel also seems to approve of offshore tax havens, and claims that 40% of the world's wealth resides in places such as Vanuatu, the Cayman Islands, Monaco and Barbados. I think it's fair to say that Thiel, like Rupert Murdoch, is against tax. He also likes the globalisation of digital culture because it makes the banking overlords hard to attack: "You can't have a workers' revolution to take over a bank if the bank is in Vanuatu," he says.

If life in the past was nasty, brutish and short, then in the future Thiel wants to make it much longer, and to this end he has also invested in a firm that is exploring life-extension technologies. He has pledged £3.5m to a Cambridge-based gerontologist called Aubrey de Grey, who is searching for the key to immortality. Thiel is also on the board of advisers of something called the Singularity Institute for Artificial Intelligence. From its fantastical website, the following: "The Singularity is the technological creation of smarter-than-human intelligence. There are several technologies ... heading in this direction ... Artificial Intelligence ... direct brain-computer interfaces ... genetic engineering ... different technologies which, if they reached a threshold level of sophistication, would enable the creation of smarter-than-human intelligence."

So by his own admission, Thiel is trying to destroy the real world, which he also calls "nature", and install a virtual world in its place, and it is in this context that we must view the rise of Facebook. Facebook is a deliberate experiment in global manipulation, and Thiel is a bright young thing in the neoconservative pantheon, with a penchant for far-out techno-utopian fantasies. Not someone I want to help get any richer."

I cracked open a two-yolk egg today and fried it.  There's something magical about eating two unborn chickens from a single shell.  Apparently it happens in about 1 out of every 1,000 eggs and with greater frequency in jumbo sized eggs.

"Throughout history and in different cultures, finding a double yolk has been considered to mean anything from an impending wedding to a financial windfall to a death in the family."

"In Europe, eggs are used to tell fortunes. An egg with a double yolk means an impending marriage, an egg with a dark spot on the yolk symbolizes a bad omen, and an egg without a yolk is plain old unlucky."

"Venerated as a symbol of life, ancient philosophers saw the egg as a symbol of the world and the four elements. The shell was seen to represent the earth; the white, water; the yolk, fire; and the fourth element, air, was found under the shell at the rounded end."

"The discovery of a double yolk within is cause for terror or celebration depending on which school of thought is followed -  some say it presages a wedding, others a death. Once the egg is consumed, its shell must be broken up lest a witch use it to gain power over the person who ate from it. A witch might also make a boat from an intact shell, then set sail in it and wreck ships at sea."

I didn't crush the shell.  Hopefully we don't have any neighbourhood witches here in Alameda, though I do like the imagery of some witch digging through our garbage bins at night, looking for my freak-egg shell.
For what it's worth, I might play some guitar after work tomorrow evening.

Oh fuck!  Lorne died:



R.I.P., Mr. Hallett.  You were only three years older than myself.

I think that I've finally lost it.  I'm currently watching this man:


....give Catholic mass on EWTN, for my own entertainment.  I guess I have never completely gleaned how fucked up Catholic mass is until this moment, and watching a mass outside of a church environment is absolutely mesmerizing.  Also, I keep habitually doing some of the responses, which is sad considering I was never baptized and never underwent catechism.  Impressive little innocuous cult you have going there, Vatican.

Another thing that has been bugging me lately are all these "money saving" tips that I keep seeing everywhere.  Some of them are actually good ideas and I can see merit in mentioning them, but the majority of the "tips" are common sense and stuff that I've always done anyway because I try to conserve resources and be efficient and not waste money.  Are there really THAT MANY people who don't save their leftovers if it's something they can reheat or reuse?  Do they need to be TOLD that they are being grossly wasteful by throwing perfectly good food out rather than putting it in a rubbermaid container and taking it to work the next day for lunch?  

This economy is a constant reminder of how much I despise modern society.

I'm watching a morning news show and they just quoted a viewer who says that her family drinks a lot of soda, so they save the cans and take them into a recycling facility for money.  That's terrific, but if you really want to save money, why don't you CUT OUT THE SODA THAT YOUR FAMILY DOES NOT NEED TO FUCKING DRINK, YOU DUMB TWAT. 

 This country really needs to learn the difference between luxury and necessity, and as much as I don't want another Great Depression, it wouldn't hurt to see a reality check of that magnitude whip this spoiled country in the backside and put things into perspective.

When I mention to others that my parents have a sailboat or that they took Ben and I to Costa Rica, they always give me a look like I must be from a family with money or something.  The truth is, my parents live comfortably because they were so good at conserving money.  When I was a kid, we had a huge garden that provided virtually all of our produce for the growing season.  We canned and froze food, picked berries from the wild, picked asparagus from the wild, made wine and beer, fished and froze extra fish for the future, kept bee hives for honey, made deals with locals for things like maple syrup or apples, shopped based upon what was on sale, sewed clothing or got hand-me-downs or rummage sale deals, and generally learned to do what we could on our own.  My dad fixed our cars and did our taxes and my mom repaired broken clothing and baked bread.  I was always included and taught, even if I wasn't interested in sewing or car repair, and it was clear early on that I was expected to pitch in with the work. 

It's not difficult to find ways to cut costs, but it does involve effort, commitment, sacrifice, and forethought.  For those reasons I do not envision much of a change in the behaviour of most Americans as none of those are typical modern American traits.  Maybe someone can come up with a "Money Saving" app. for the iPhone that shocks you when you are doing something dumb.

Another money saving tip just viewed on the news show: stop buying diet/healthy foods!

*HEAD TO DESK*

*sobbing quietly in the dark*

We are seriously doomed, either to a real life version of "Idiocracy" or the impending apocalypse.

I gave myself a haircut last night. Well, I gave myself the first part of a haircut. Photo forthcoming upon completion.  For now, here is a photo of I like of me with my mom's old hippie head scarf, pre-haircut.  I stayed up until 6 AM earlier this week learning how to tie various scarves in sundry manners, because I am a nerd.

Generalissimo/Ferocious Eagle/Ovipositor show tonight in Berkeley at Starry Plough.  I remember Cecil/Robert talking once on LJ about how the etymology of plough is related to "fuck" in Old Germanic, so everytime I think "Starry Plough" it comes out "Starry Fuck" in my head.  Starry, Starry Fuck.

Fucking the fields.
Snowfuck.
Fuckman.
Fucking engines.
Fuck Horse.
Mouldboard Fucking.

We got a surprise shipment of cardigans in at work today in every available colour, so of course I had to buy three of them (charcoal, emerald, coral).  They're the very simple solid coloured, round necked 1950s styled ones that I adore and they're only $14 each after my discount.  I do not need to be spending more money on clothing this month but a cardigan is tough to pass up and I know I'll wear the piss out of them, especially since my bosses insist on keeping the front doors open at all times because Californians are apparently too retarded to walk into shops with closed doors.

Ben brought me a gorgeous bouquet of irises last night, which is currently sitting in a plain old pint glass because I don't have a large vase.  I'm going to hop over to the Salvation Army and see if I can remedy that problem and run a few other errands before fine tuning my haircut and heading off to the show tonight.

I just ordered $45 worth of hot and extra-hot giardiniera. 

Yes, I know I can make giardiniera.  I have made it before.  In truth, it would cost me more to buy the ingredients and then throw them out when the giardiniera goes bad due to lack of preservatives.

I can't wait to devour a tasty Chicago-style Italian Beef sandwich.  Mmm...hot dipped.

Making happy "buy our clothing!"  iPod playlists for work:

Un bel di, vidremo
Levarsi un fil di fumo sull’estremo
Confin del mare.
E poi la nave appare.
Poi la nave bianca
Entra nel porto, rumba il suo saluto.
Vedi? E venuto!
Io non gli scendo incontro. Io no.
Mi metto
La sul ciglio del colle e aspetto, e aspetto
Gran tempo e non mi pesa
La lunga attesa.
E…uscito dalla folla cittadina
Un uom, un picciol punto
S’avvia per la collina.
Chi sara? Chi sara?
E come sra giunto?
Che dira? Che dira?
Chiamera Butterfly dalla lontana.
Io senza dar risposta
Me ne staro nascosta
Un po’ per celia, e un po’ per non morire
Al primo incontro, ed egli alquanto in pena
Chiamera, chiamera:
“Piccina mogliettina
Olezzo di verbena,”
I nomi che mi dava al suo venire.
Tutto questo avvera, te lo prometto.
Tienti la tua paura, - io con sucura
Fede l’aspetto.

 

One fine day, we’ll notice
A thread of smoke arising on the sea
In the far horizon,
And then the ship appearing.
Then the trim white vessel
Glides into the harbor,
Thunders forth her cannon.
See you? He is coming!
I do not go to meet him.
Not I. I stay
Upon the brow of the hillock and wait, and wait
For a long time, but never weary
Of the long waiting.
From out the crowded city,
There is coming a man –
A little speck in the distance, climbing the hillock.
Can you guess who it is?
And when he’s reached the summit
Can you guess what he’ll say?
He will call “Butterfly” from the distance.
I, without answering,
Hold myself quietly concealed,
A bit to tease him, and a bit so as not to die
At our first meeting; and then, a little troubled,
He will call, he will call:
“Dear baby-wife of mine, dear little orange-blossom!
The names he used to call me when he came here.
This will all come to pass, just as I tell you.
Banish your idle fears – for he’ll return, I know it.


No he won't, Butterfly.  No he won't.
Still awake.  I have 3.5 hours of sleep ahead of me.  I am going to bed again.

Bring the hail!  Bring the hail!

I'm glad the weather suits my moods.
Back from Costa Rica/30th Birthday...photos coming eventually!  For now, it is off to bed to rest before working an unscheduled shift tomorrow.

Huh.  My left eye just temporarily went almost completely blind for about 15 seconds.  I could only see one small oval of light in the center.   I wonder what that's about?

If I die in my sleep tonight or anything, it's been nice knowing all of you.

Currently downloading lots of Neil Young and David Bowie. From the Wikipedia of "The Man Who Sold The World": In the wake of this cover, Bowie bemoaned the fact that when he performed the number himself he would encounter "kids that come up afterwards and say, 'It's cool you're doing a Nirvana song.' And I think, 'Fuck you, you little tosser!'
I think that I'm going to go back to school for photography.

I know that a few of you on my friends list sew, so I thought I'd ask you for your input about sewing machines.

I'm looking to purchase a sewing machine (either used or new).  I'd like to steer clear of digital  as much as possible because of obvious issues with repairing a digital machine vs. analog or mostly analog.

What I know that I would use said machine for is simple clothing alterations--hemming, taking in or letting out seams, turning dresses into shirts and making simple A-line skirts and the like.  I might need a serging/surging/serger (whatever it's called) stitch option or something close to it for stuff like sewing figure skating leggings or leotards.

I would prefer something that would be capable of basic quilting.  I don't want to make crazy complex art quilts; just normal old patchwork quilting if anything.  This isn't THAT big of a deal but it would be nice if the machine had the capability of producing a machine-quilted bedding piece.

A couple of random things:

-I've never really sewed before.  My mom is, like, ninja master of all things stitched, but I never took much of an interest in any of it when I was growing up.  I've learned tidbits about quilting, cross stitch, embroidery, and sewing but I never embraced those things as hobbies.  Thus, I'm starting at a pretty beginner level though I'm not entirely clueless (I know about cutting on the bias, I have stitched button holes before, I kind of remember how to put a zipper into a skirt, etc).

-I don't want to spend $300 on a machine and find that I don't use it for anything other than hemming pants.  On the flipside, I also do not want to buy a super basic machine for $60 and then find out that I really love sewing and have to spend more money to get a second machine to satisfy my needs.

I want something basic but not so basic that it is restrictive.



I'm also thinking about trying to get my hands on a used band saw.  It turns out that as I age, I turn into my parents.  If I suddenly start reading books about building my own log cabin or sailboat riggings, please administer a good beating about my head and shoulders.

"Table for five which included Doctor, Nurse, Nurse, Nurse, and Psychotherapist.  So in the middle of dinner when someone ran into the restaurant and screamed "Is there a doctor in the house someone just got hit by a car!!!"  Well you've never seen a table empty a restaurant so fast.  Sadly a woman was killed in the intersection of Pine and Fillmore and my friends were the first on the scene and its one of those reminders that we don't live in a TV show where CPR brings someone back to life.  I decided to skip the situation as my skills would not have been helpful in that moment and gawking at trauma is really not my bag.  

Anyway - the waitstaff at SPQR was really cool and bought us our wine for the evening after everyone returned in a very somber mood.  This was great for two reasons - alcohol is actually really helpful in traumatic situations as it keeps you numb and sometimes that is what you need.  It was also helpful because the pasta had so much friggin salt on it I felt like I was going to turn into a piece of Petesciutto - HA!!!  Get it - not Prosciutto but Petesciutto cause my name is Peter.........

Sorry Death kind of kills my sense of humor.....HA!  get it death kills my sense of humor......

Woo - tip your waiter and I'm available for funerals and weddings!  Thank you good night!!!!"

"I went on a date with myself the other night to SPQR. As you can see below, my first time eating here was a bit somber but not one to let death cast its long shadow on my choices in life I returned undaunted. That last sentence is a little too inflated for Yelp but hey when in Rome......HA! SPQR - when in Rome!! Oh god its so easy.

Moving on, if you've ever met me you quickly realize that I like the person I am very much and this evokes one of two responses: One - you like yourself too and we laugh loudly, drink heavily, and make others wonder how we are having such a good time; Second response - you want to punch me in the face because you've got some self-esteem issues and for whatever reason I act as a catalyst for these issues. So the best solution for this unfortunate dichotomy in reaction is to often just go it alone and date myself.

So as I sat at the chef's bar area in the back of SPQR and took my time eating ricotta with beets, chanterelle mushrooms with spinach, and fried pig ears with stone ground mustard well I thought a little small talk was in order as the awkward silence that often accompanies dates with yourself was weighing heavy.

ME - Hello
me- Hello
ME - What are you reading?
me - a magazine.
ME - I'm sorry do you want to be left alone?
me - No it's fine. I mean I'm sitting at the bar alone eating dinner, reading a magazine, and perfectly content but I would love to stop enjoying myself and talk to a stranger.
ME - A stranger! How dare you! We've been sleeping together for 32 years!
me - Oh don't pull that sleeping together line on me again. I was very clear from the beginning that this was going to be an open relationship.
ME - (tears start to swell) I just never thought it would be this hard.
me - Yeah, well that's your issue not mine.
ME - I hate you!!!
me - That's fine cause I love myself and don't need your approval to do so.
ME - Why do you torture me Peter M???? Just a snippet of your time here and there is all I ask but always with the sarcasm and over compensating with the humor, but you know I can't leave. Oh god why does it hurt so much to love you????

Well, I will you tell you one thing. I am not going out with myself again for a long time cause that bitch has issues and almost ruined a perfect meal at SPQR."

A: What accessories do you wear everyday?
My diamond ring, some other ring(s) and usually bracelets.  I wear barrettes quite often as well.

B: What is your beauty routine?
In the morning, I shower.  At night, I wash my face with some Burt's Bees Orange Cleanser. If my skin is dry I use lotion.

C: What was the last item of clothing (for yourself) that you purchased?
I bought some red leggings and a rhinestone necklace/earring set from work tonight.!

D: Do you use a dresser, closet, or both?
Both, as well as storage bins under the bed.  I wish I could fit another dresser in our apartment.

E: What type of earrings are in your ears right now?
I tend to not wear earrings unless I'm dressing up fancy for something.

F: What type of figure do you have (measurements)?
38-30-38

G: Do you wear glasses?
Yes.  I have three pairs of frames in addition to contacts.

H: What type of handbag do you carry?
It depends.  I tend to like large square handbags or else a tote.

I: What is your ideal style?
1930s Movie Star or else Insane 1950s Housewife

J: What is your favorite brand of jeans?
Levi's

k: Do you wear knee high stocking?
Yes.

L: Do you *have* to wear matching lingerie?
No, but I at least like to not wear a white bra with plain black panties if I can help it.

M: Do you wear makeup?
Yes.  I am a lipstick fanatic.  The only cosmetic product I don't wear is mascara, though every so often I'll put some on and then remember why I don't wear it (my eyelashes are too long and the mascara weighs them down, causing my eyelids to get sore).

N: Do you wear nightgowns?
Yes I do, both silk and cotton ones.

O: What outerwear do you put on when going out on a typical winters day?
Are we talking Wisconsin winter of California winter?  Here, it's usually a sweatshirt, gloves and a hat.  In Wisconsin, it's much, much more than that.

P: What is your favorite perfume?
Vivienne Westwood's 'Boudoir" or "Libertine," both discontinued and both worth every penny of the $60/bottle.

Q: Is your motto "quality over quantity" when it comes to clothing and accessories?
Yes, though quality does not necessarily mean name brand or expensive.  However, I'd take a nice cashmere sweater from T.J. Maxx any day over ten $5/each clearance rack poorly made flimsy shirts from Forever 21.

R: Do you wear rain boots?
I haven't had a need to until I moved out here.  I'm going to buy some from work when we get the next shipment in, since I wasn't crazy about the prints we currently have.

S: Do you wear socks or slippers when your feet get cold?
Socks.  I wear slippers when I'm in a garage or basement, or if I need to go outside the house for something.

T: Do you have a set of travel luggage?
Yes.  It is forest green and I have three pieces.  One of the suitcases is so large that I doubt it can even be used on a plane under the post-9/11 baggage restrictions.  If you filled it, it would be overweight.

U: What is your daily uniform?
I do not have one.  I usually dress to fit my mood and since my employer has no dress code, I don't have to look a certain way.

V: If you are married, did you wear a veil with your wedding dress? If not, how did you do your hair?
No.   I wore my hair down and I took a shower before the wedding and probably put some pomade in it.  I wore a short black Chinese-style dress with red embroidery on it, black fishnet stockings and black mary jane heels.  The groom wore neon green pants made out of muppet fur and a blue button up shirt.

W: Do you wear a watch?
Sometimes.  I have several but I usually don't care what time it is enough to warrant wearing one.

X: What item of clothing always makes you feel beautiful?
A really flattering, glamorous dress

Y: What is your favorite type of yarn?
Cashmere or merino wool

Z: Do you prefer zippers or buttons?
Pants and hoodies=zippers.  Everything else=buttons

This cracked me up.



Praying to false idols golden bulls.  Priceless!

I'm not by any means an atheist but sometimes I wonder what runs through the heads of the deeply religious and how they can possibly justify their actions.  They have to smell their own crap occasionally, right?

American women's gymnastic team (and particularly Alicia Sacramone):

I know that it sucks that you messed up on the beam and floor and missed the gold medal in the team final.  However, please keep in mind that at least three of the underage girls on the Chinese team are UGLY AS SIN.  They are jaw-droppingly, astonishingly unattractive, and it's not even that they're at the awkward age of 13 *ahem*...16 and they look a bit odd because of it.  They simply have the bone structure and facial features of a beaten and drowned rat in a wind tunnel.

You may not have gotten the gold medal, ladies, but at least when you have sex in the future the other person won't have to keep a bucket at beside the bed to collect the vomit that your face and freakish skeletal body inspire in your partner.

Also...did a crate of Wet n' Wild eyeshadow lost at sea in the mid-1980s wash up on China's beaches recently?

i will sail to the far shore,
and i will chop a hole in the hull too big to repair,
and i will turn the soil with my hands,
and i will make my home there.
my garden will grow so high.
my garden will grow so high.
that i will be completely hidden.

i will go where i will go,
and i will jettison all dead weight,
and i will use these words for kindling,
and i will sleep by the garden gate.
my garden will grow so high.
my garden will grow so high.
that i will be completely hidden

Hey, persons in the Bay Area!

Ben's band, Guitar vs. Gravity, is playing a show at the Stork Club on September 6th.  The opening bands are sort of pop punkish and G vs. G is not, so there needs to be sort of a 'tween band for the crowd.  I don't have many friends here and the "scene" here has mostly made me want to smack it in the face.  I get annoyed when people assume that I don't know my shit because I don't have 8 tattoos declaring my love for _____ running down my arms and hair that I probably wore my freshman year of university.  

Do you have any suggestions?

Setting: Old Navy, as our protagonist shops for business casual "trousers""

*I run a tight Brit-friendly journal

19 year old #1: She's in Italy for 3 weeks.

19 year old #2: Italy? Huh. I'd...I'd be scared to travel abroad.

19 year old #1: Why?

19 year old #2: I wouldn't know what to do. I mean, if it were Florida, I'd go to Disneyworld. But it it were Italy...where would I go?

Yeah, you spoiled little cuntmuffin...wherever would you go to find entertainment in Italy? The horrors.  The decisions. The sacrifice.

Fuck California.

And of course, the night I was actually in the mood to write a bit of something on here and catch up on emailing, I cut the tip of my middle finger with the butcher knife while doing dishes...

At least it's the right hand so I can start playing guitar again if I am so inclined.

They sat together in the park
As the evening sky grew dark,
She looked at him and he felt a spark tingle to his bones.
'Twas then he felt alone and wished that he'd gone straight
And watched out for a simple twist of fate.

They walked along by the old canal
A little confused, I remember well
And stopped into a strange hotel with a neon burnin' bright.
He felt the heat of the night hit him like a freight train
Moving with a simple twist of fate.

A saxophone someplace far off played
As she was walkin' by the arcade.
As the light bust through a beat-up shade where he was wakin' up,
She dropped a coin into the cup of a blind man at the gate
And forgot about a simple twist of fate.

He woke up, the room was bare
He didn't see her anywhere.
He told himself he didn't care, pushed the window open wide,
Felt an emptiness inside to which he just could not relate
Brought on by a simple twist of fate.

He hears the ticking of the clocks
And walks along with a parrot that talks,
Hunts her down by the waterfront docks where the sailers all come in.
Maybe she'll pick him out again, how long must he wait
Once more for a simple twist of fate.

People tell me it's a sin
To know and feel too much within.
I still believe she was my twin, but I lost the ring.
She was born in spring, but I was born too late
Blame it on a simple twist of fate.
Ben's band, Guitar vs. Gravity, has a show in SF this Friday. You should come out.

I went down the the gas station for no particular reason,
heard the screams from the high school --
it's football season.
empty lot the station faces, will probably be there forever.
I climbed over the four foot fence,
I was trying to sever the tether.
moon in the sky, cold as a stone
spend each night in your arms, always wake up alone.

I lay down in the weeds, it was a real cold night.
I was happy until the overnight attendant switched on the floodlight.
walking home I was talking to you under my breath,
saying things I would never say directly.
I heard a siren on the road highway ahead.
kinda wish they'd come and get me
frost on the sidewalk, white as a bone
tried to get close to you again, always wake up alone.

and as i was crossing our doorstep,
i hesitated just a moment there.
remembered the day we moved into our small house
'til the vision got too vivid to bear.

you were almost asleep, halfway undressed
i lay right down next to you
held your head against my chest.
and a guy with any kind of courage
would maybe stop to think the matter through
maybe hold you still and raise the question,
instead of blindly holding on to you.
but we crank up the heat
and you giggle and moan,
spend all night in the company of ghosts, always wake up alone

Now that I have a job secured with a normal weekly schedule that includes every Wednesday off, I've decided that I'm going to try to start figure skating once a week.  The Oakland Ice Center has daytime public skating and while sharing the ice with the commoners comes with disadvantages, I haven't been on skates since I was 25 and chances are I'm not going to be launching into flying camels for quite some time.  I'll be lucky if I can still do a waltz jump or forward cross-overs without tripping and landing in a klutzy heap.

What do skaters even wear these days?  God, do I feel old...

The more that I read reviews on Yelp, the more that I think that I need to teach classes on how to be a human.  And live.  Doing human things rather than being a spoiled, wilting little cunt who relies on others to do everything for them and is outraged when a fly shows up and has the audacity to land on the lip of a wine glass.

Upon looking at the reviews for the lake near Livermore which we are presumably going tomorrow, I made the following observations:

1) You are complaining about an hour drive from Oakland?  Are you fucking serious?!?!  I couldn't even go to a decent restaurant for most of my life without driving that far.  Grocery shopping took 30 minutes each way.

2) You went out for a day on the lake and you brought Fromage D'Affinois along?  I love that stuff but...jesus.  Were you going out of your way to be a pretentious twat or does it just come naturally to you?

3) Oh no!  You had to pay an additional $2 per dog to get them into the park.  How awful that the park makes you pay extra for bringing in a high-speed shitting machine.

4)  "Beer drinking fishermen."  As opposed to what?  The straightedge fishermen who go out on the lake not to catch fish but to inform them of their rights as valuable members of the food chain?

My new thing is that, while walking, I go out of my way to not move or slow down for idiots paying attention to their cellphones instead of NOT RUNNING INTO OTHER PEOPLE.  It's too bad that I can't line my clothing from the inside out with poison darts.

I told Ben tonight that I will probably become a serial killer in a few more years.  He seemed fine with that.

If I never throw up again, I will be a happy lady.  Jesus H. Christ...

I hope that this Pedialyte kicks in soon.

I guess I'll be voting for the Socialist candidate this year, come November.
